I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
programmatic approach for the Third Financial Sector Program and (ii) a proposed policy-based 
loan to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 1 of the Third Financial Sector Program. The 
report  describes  proposed  Implementing  subprogram  2  of  the  Third  Financial  Sector  Program 
technical  assistance  (TA),  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1
 
 
2. 
The development framework for Cambodia’s finance sector is based on a 10-year rolling 
finance  sector  development  strategy  (FSDS)  of  the  government.  The  10-year  strategy  was 
recently  updated    as  the  FSDS,  2011–2020.2
   It  is  aligned  with  Cambodia’s  updated  National 
Strategy  and  Development  Plan,  2009–2013  and  Rectangular  Strategy,  as  well  as  with  the 
country  strategy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  Cambodia,  2011–2013.  It  has 
incorporated  the  recommendations  of  the  Financial  Sector  Assessment  Program,  2010  of  the 
International  Monetary  Fund  and  the  World  Bank.  Bilateral  meetings  were  held  with  key 
stakeholders and were followed by several workshops with government agencies. Development 
partner  coordination  was  further  strengthened  during  the  update  of  the  FSDS.  ADB  meets 
regularly  with  all  development  partners  in  the  finance  sector  to  discuss  current  issues  and 
coordinate activities. This informal group of development partners periodically discusses finance 
issues  with  relevant  business  associations  and  Cambodia’s  Private  Sector  Forum.  As  per  the 
Government  of  Cambodia’s  request,  the  proposed  third  program  is  a  cluster  of  three 
subprograms to implement the first phase of the FSDS, 2011–2020. These reforms have been 
discussed  with  all  relevant  government  agencies,  industry  associations,  and  development 
partners. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
A  robust  finance  sector  is  essential  for  sustainable  economic  growth.  Cambodia’s  real 
gross domestic product (GDP) grew strongly at 9.1% per year on average from 1998 to 2008. 
This slowed in 2009 and 2010 because of indirect effects of the recent global economic crisis. 
The authorities nevertheless aim to pursue economic reform that will return the economy to pre-
crisis growth rates. The period of robust economic performance was led by the private sector, in 
particular  garments,  tourist-related  services,  construction,  and  agriculture.  A  substantial 
proportion  of  these  activities  were  financed  by  foreign  direct  investment  and  the  domestic 
finance  system.  With  a  rapidly  growing  commercial  economy  that  requires  a  sound  finance 
system  to  sustain  growth,  the  government  is  committed  to  the  long-term  development  of  the 
finance  sector,  channeling  financial  resources  to  productive  investments,  and  managing  the 
inherent  risks  to  achieve  sustainable  economic  growth  over  the  long  term  and  contribute  to 
poverty  reduction.  To  promote  sustainable  economic  growth,  reduce  poverty,  and  mitigate 
shocks  emanating  from  external  financial  crises,  ADB  supports  finance  sector  development  in 
its developing member countries, including Cambodia. Since 2001, ADB has become the lead 
development partner supporting Cambodia’s finance sector.

Fully  cognizant of  the  pivotal  role the  sector  would  play  in  achieving  economic transformation, 
and faced with a rapidly growing commercial economy potentially undermined by scarce capital, 
the  government  embarked  on  a  long-term  development  strategy  and  plan  for  developing  the 
country’s  finance  sector.  As  a  first  step,  and  with  ADB  assistance,  the  government 
commissioned  the  preparation  of  the  FSDS,  2001–2010,  which  was  to  guide  finance  sector 
development  during  that  period.  To  help  implement  the  first  phase  of  the  FSDS,  2001–2010, 
ADB approved the $30 million first Financial Sector Program in November 2001.3
 Implemented 
from  2001  to  2007,  the  first  program  enabled  the  government  to  begin  establishing  legal  and 
regulatory  foundations,  consolidate  the  banking  system,  establish  key  regulatory  agencies, 
privatize  state-owned  banks  and  finance  institutions,  and  commence  the  licensing  of  informal 
microfinance institutions (MFIs). 
 
5. 
The FSDS, 2001–2010 was updated by the FSDS, 2006–2015 to take into account new 
challenges,  both  domestic  and  international,  as  well  as  market  developments.  The  FSDS, 
2006–2015  noted  encouraging  progress  in  sector  development.  Encouraging  achievements 
under  the  first  program  prompted  the  government  to  request  further  support  from  ADB  to 
continue its reform of the finance sector, and ADB approved the $45.3 million Second Financial 
Sector  Program  Cluster  in  December  2007. 4
 Implemented  from  2007  to  2010,  the  second 
program completed reforms that helped boost confidence in the formal finance sector, advanced 
the  legal  and  regulatory  foundation,  strengthened  the  capacity  of  regulatory  agencies,  and 
introduced part of the supporting infrastructure for financial activities. While Cambodia still has 
one of the lowest rates of financial intermediation in the world, it has improved since 2001 with 
the money supply growing from 13% of GDP in 2001 to 21% in 2006 and 40% in 2010.

8.          Sector  Challenges.  Challenges  to  further  developing  the  finance  sector  include  low 
financial  intermediation  due  to  the  rural  and  informal  nature  of  the  economy,  vulnerability  to 
external  shocks  due  to  a  narrow  economic  base  that  is  heavily  dependent  on  international 
markets, governance issues as accounting and auditing practices are being further developed, 
and  inefficiencies due to a financial infrastructure that is not fully developed and corresponding 
technical  capacity  that  is  weak  and  needs  to  be  further  developed  in  line  with  the  human 
capacity requirements of the sector. The third program will continue to address these challenges 
as outlined in the Outputs Section (paras 12-25 below). 

9. 
Lessons. In moving to implement the FSDS, 2011–2020, past lessons clearly illustrate 
the  following:  (i)  A  set  of  long-term  objectives  is  required  to  guide  and  shape  medium-term 
policy design and implementation. (ii) Flexibility in design is important to accommodate changes 
in  economic,  social,  and  political  circumstances.  (iii)  The  time  lag  between  the  adoption  of 
reforms  and  their  effective  enforcement  needs  to  be  shortened.  (iv)  Substantial  TA  resources 
are  required  to  build  technical  capacity.  (v)  Maintaining  monetary  and  financial  stability  are 
crucial to economic growth. (vi) Promoting good governance, under which financial growth and 
development is to be pursued, would anchor the FSDS. (vii) Enhancing the sector’s operational 
efficiency  would  facilitate  FSDS  implementation.  The  design  of  the  third  program  has 
incorporated these lessons. 
 
Rebuilding  Cambodia’s  finance  sector.  This  is  a  protracted  process.  While  positive

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The  expected impact of the third program is a sound, market-based finance sector able 
to  enhance  resource  mobilization  and  support  sustainable  economic  growth.  The  expected 
outcome  is  a  growing,  resilient,  and  efficient  financial  system. The  third  program  comprises  a 
series  of  three  single-tranche  subprograms  to  be  implemented  from  December  2010  to 
December  2013.  Subprogram  1  has  20  reform  actions,  which  the  government  implemented 
between December 2010 and October 2011. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

12. 
Third program policy measures include a set of sector reforms to improve the legal and 
regulatory  framework  and  its  application,  strengthen  institutional  coordination  among  national 
regulatory agencies, promote confidence and growth in outreach, strengthen the application of 
supporting  infrastructure  and  international  standards,  develop  new  markets,  and  support 
capacity  development  more  sustainably.  The  program  has  four  outputs:  (i)  finance  sector 
stability maintained, (ii) confidence and financial intermediation improved, (iii) good governance 
promoted,  and  (iv)  finance  sector  efficiency  enhanced.  Key  activities  for  each  output  are 
described below. 
 

1. 

Finance Sector Stability Maintained 

13. 
Legal and regulatory framework for banks and microfinance institutions. As part of 
efforts  to  maintain  financial  stability,  address  the  features  of  a  fast-changing  domestic  market, 
and align it with the reality of closer international economic integration, the NBC is committed to 
updating the Law on the Organization and Conduct of the NBC, 1996 and the Law on Banking 
and  Financial  Institutions,  1999.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  NBC  organized  workshops  in 
coordination  with  the  MEF,  Ministry  of  Commerce  (MOC),  SECC,  and  stakeholders  to  identify 
which  existing  laws  have  overlapping  or  conflicting  provisions.  Under  subprogram  2,  the  NBC 
will update these two laws in consultation with the MEF, MOC, and SECC and incorporate the 
recommendations of the Financial Sector Assessment Program, 2010. 
 
14. 
Bank  supervision  capacity  and  financial  stability.  As  part  of  efforts  to  strengthen 
prudential supervision under subprogram 1, the NBC has developed a framework for assessing 
finance  sector  risks  and  issued  supervisory  guidelines  to  banks,  adopted  a  road  map  toward 
improving  compliance  with  core  Basel  principles  for  effective  bank  supervision,  and  reinforced 
coordination  between  the  NBC’s  Supervision  Department  and  the  Cambodian  Financial 
Intelligence Unit (CAFIU) to enforce reporting by banks. Subprogram 2 will support (i) the NBC’s 
efforts  to  strengthen  cooperation  among  local  finance  sector  regulators  and  with  supervision 
authorities in countries that have subsidiary banks licensed in Cambodia, (ii) its requirement that 
banks  involved  in  nonbank  activities  provide  consolidated  financial  statements,  and  (iii)  its 
implementation  of  key  actions  toward  full  compliance  with  core  Basel  principles  for  effective 
bank supervision.

made  significant  progress  in  building  the  regulatory  framework  for  licensing  and  supervising 
registered MFIs. To improve financial reporting by MFIs, the NBC recently required them to pilot 
test a microfinance information system that electronically transmits MFIs’ financial reports to the

Good Governance Promoted 

21. 
International initiatives on anti-money laundering and combating the financing of 
terrorism. The second program commenced activities to implement anti-money laundering and 
combating  the  financing  of  terrorism  (AML/CFT)  in  Cambodia,  to  support  international 
deterrence  efforts  and  standard  governance  principles  and  build  market  confidence.  Under

assessment  framework  and  strategic  implementation  plan;  and  conduct  workshops  to  raise 
awareness of AML/CFT among casinos, nonprofit organizations, and realtors. 
 
22. 
Corporate  governance  and  transparency  in  the  finance  sector.  To build consumer 
confidence  in  the  sector,  formal  finance  institutions  have  to  be  more  transparent  in  how  they 
conduct business and consistently implement good governance practices. Under subprogram 1,
